{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{moresources|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox event | title = Kill Haole Day | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | english_name = | time = | duration = | date = The last day of school (May or June) | venue = | location = [[Hawaii]] | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also_known_as = | type = | theme = | cause = | motive = | first_reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organisers = <!-- or |organizers= --> | filmed_by = | participants = | outcome = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | reported deaths = | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | trial = | verdict = | convictions = | sentence = | publication_bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | blank_label = <!-- or |blank_data= --> | blank1_label = <!-- or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }} '''Kill Haole Day''' is an event that has occurred in some [[Hawaiia]]n schools, when non-white students are said to harass and sometimes attack [[White Hawaiian]] students.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Kill Haole Day|author=Community Relations Commission|journal=New community|volume=7–8|page=267|issn=0047-9586|oclc=615546790|quote=My students talked of the High Schools' 'Kill Haole Day' when a day in the school year was dedicated to roughing up the whites.}}</ref>
In his 2009 book, lawyer and former Hawai{{okina}}i governor [[Ben Cayetano]] wrote that "Kill Haole Day" began as a news story headline about an incident between [[haole]] and local (not just Hawaiian) students. After that, "whenever there was a fight or an incident between haole and non-haole students, the news media", and newspaper editorial boards, "repeatedly reprised 'Kill Haole Day' in their news stories".<ref>Cayetano, Ben. ''Ben: A Memoir, From Street Kid to Governor'' (Watermark, 2009), p. 531</ref>
In 1999, School Superintendent Paul LeMahieu said he was aware of "kill haole day" but not aware of any recent incidents. Also, in 1999, it became an issue for [[hate crimes]] legislation.<ref name="starbulletin">{{cite web|url=http://starbulletin.com/1999/03/24/news/story7.html|title=‘Kill haole day’ linked to hate-crime bill}}</ref>
Newspaper columnist Lee Cataluna wrote in 2010, "In terms of actual, first-person, eyewitness accounts of Kill Haole Day, no one had any [incidents] that happened in the last three decades. Not one teacher, not one police officer, not one victim or perpetrator."<ref>{{cite news|author=Catalune, Lee|title=Responses refute existence of any recent 'Kill Haole Day'|work=Honolulu Advertiser|date=November 23, 2010|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/20101123_responses_refute_existence_of_any_recent_kill_haole_day.html}}</ref>
On December 31, 2008, the U.S. Department of Education released a report that concluded there was "substantial evidence that students experienced racially and sexually derogatory name-calling on nearly a daily basis on school buses, at school bus stops, in school hallways and other areas of the school".<ref>{{cite web|author=United States Department of Education - Office for Civil Rights|title=OCR Reference No 10051060|url=http://stopsexualassaultinschools.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/OCR-FOIA-cases-Hawaii.pdf}}</ref>
The report also concluded that school officials responded inadequately or not at all when students complained of racial harassment. Students who did complain were retaliated against by their antagonists.<ref>{{cite news|author=Southern Poverty Law Center,|title=Hawaii Suffering From Racial Prejudice|url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-report/browse-all-issues/2009/fall/prejudice-in-paradise}}</ref>
